awd_titl_txt: Eradication of Biofilms in Metal Working Fluids
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal working fluids are applied in many manufacturing processes to ensure reduced tool wear and improved work piece quality. Worldwide, more than half a billion gallons of metal working fluids are consumed annually. Microbial contamination is a significant factor in the degradation of these fluids, causing biofouling and corrosion of equipment, imperilment of product quality, and posing occupational safety risks. Once metal working fluids are microbially contaminated, removing bacteria is a difficult task. Residual bacteria can quickly repopulate, even after meticulous cleaning and recharge procedures. Microbial biofilms within the inaccessible regions of a working fluid system are likely responsible for the rapid post-cleaning repopulation. Biofilms are attached microbial communities whose function depends on complex social interactions. Quorum sensing provides the means for biofilm cells to communicate and collectively control group behavior. This award supports fundamental research on quorum sensing inhibition strategies to reduce/eliminate biofilm formation. Research results can help to increase the sustainability of metal working fluids, reduce waste, and help limit occupational exposure to potentially pathogenic bacteria inhabiting the fluids. This is a very large concern in manufacturing, with applications in automotive, aerospace, medical products and defense industries, and therefore directly and positively impacts American economic welfare and national security. The award includes funding of outreach activities, especially for attraction of Native American students into engineering. 

A three-year study at the Center for Biofilm Engineering at Montana State University will be performed to improve metal working fluid management using an eco-friendly alternative to remove biofilms residing within metal working fluid circulation systems. Using a two-phase approach, economically feasible agents will be screened for their ability to effectively reduce/eliminate biofilm forming organisms in metal working fluids. Phase one will involve screening a matrix of chemical/synthetic quorum sensing inhibition agents, bacterial pigments, and bioengineered enzymes for their ability to eradicate biofilm in microplate assays. The most efficacious agents would be optimized to remove biofilm, both singly and in combination with standard biocide treatments. Phase two would scale up experiments on selected agents to determine suppression/removal of biofilm in MWF circulation systems including CDC bioreactors and a fully functional, autoclavable model of a CNC milling machine designed and built by a student capstone team.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In many manufacturing processes, metal working fluids (MWFs) are applied to ensure reduced tool wear and workpiece quality. Microbial contamination of these fluids is a significant factor in the biofouling of equipment and MWFs. Once a MWF transportation system is microbially contaminated, removing bacteria from all parts of the system is a difficult task. Residual bacteria can quickly repopulate a MWF system even after meticulous cleaning, with biofilm residing within the inaccessible regions of the system believed to be responsible for this rapid repopulation.

Biofilms are attached microbial communities whose function depends on complex social interactions. Quorum sensing provides the means for biofilm cells to communicate, synchronize social interaction, and collectively control group behavior. We tested the hypothesis that quorum quenching (QQ) effectively inhibits biofilm formation in MWF; with the overall objective to improve MWF management strategies through a cost effective, ecofriendly alternative to remove biofilms within MFW circulation systems.

Phase one of the project involved screening a matrix of chemical/synthetic QQ agents and bacterial pigments for their ability to eradicate biofilm in microplate assays. The most efficacious QQ agents were optimized to remove biofilm, both singly and in combination with standard biocide treatments. Phase two involved scaled up experiments on selected QQ agents to determine suppression/removal of biofilm in MWF circulation systems including CDC bioreactors and a fully autoclavable model of a CNC milling machine designed and built by a student capstone team. In order to accommodate work with a model biofilm forming bacteria we redesigned the CNC system for biosafety level 2 (BSL2) organisms. We have published a paper on the inhibition of quorum sensing in the Journal of Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology.

A critical outcome of our work has been the development of a novel impedance-based biofilm detection sensor. Detecting when biofilm growth reaches a certain threshold can provide machining operators information necessary to decide whether or not to clean their systems or add inhibiting agents to cut down on this growth. We have shown that EIS microsensors can detect four stages of biofilm contamination: (i) initial biofilm attachment to the sensor substrate, (ii) early-stage irreversible biofilm proliferation characterized by sparse biofilm coverage, (iii) mature biofilm detection characterized by uniform biofilm coverage, and (iv) changes due to detachment and regrowth of biofilm. Several papers have been published on the developed sensors in the Journal of Industrial Microbiology and Biotechnology, Journal of Biosensors and Bioelectronics, and the IEEE Journal of Microelectromechanical Systems.

Our approach using sensors to detect biofilm and quorum sensing inhibitors to disrupt its formation holds significant potential for a number of related fields such as water treatment or where control of membrane biofouling and circulation systems are important. Given the growing resistance of microbial communities to commonly applied biocides this approach can be extended to other industrial applications.

This project has supported the training of a chemical engineering undergraduate student, three mechanical engineering technology undergraduates, a mechanical engineering undergraduate, a mechanical engineering PhD student and a senior lab scientist.
